verses.text: A word aptly spoken is like apples of gold in settings of silver.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 25:11
rsbNotes.text: 25:11 Lit. “Apples of gold in settings of silver, a word fitly spoken.” This kind of proverbial comparison simply places two or more things side by side (cf. v. 18), leaving the reader to work out the nature of the comparison. The importance of well-chosen words, a common wisdom theme, is highlighted by their comparison with objects of fine craftsmanship.

verses.text: Like an earring of gold or an ornament of fine gold is a wise man's rebuke to a listening ear.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 25:12
rsbNotes.text: 25:12 A similar comparison of ideas is found in v. 11. Two pieces of jewelry are set alongside a good relationship between the wise teacher’s rebuke and the receptive pupil. The implied comparison says either that a rebuke is as valuable as fine gold jewelry, or that a wise rebuke and a receptive ear go together like matched jewelry.

verses.text: Like the coolness of snow at harvest time is a trustworthy messenger to those who send him; he refreshes the spirit of his masters.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 25:13
rsbNotes.text: 25:13 Like the cold of snow. The imagery is not of an unseasonable snowfall, which would be disastrous for the harvest, but of refreshment (cf. v. 25).

verses.text: Like clouds and wind without rain is a man who boasts of gifts he does not give.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 25:14
rsbNotes.text: 25:14 Inhabitants of Palestine often experienced clouds that promised rain but proved to be dry (Jude 12). Such a proverb today might be applied to those who seek power and influence, whether political or personal, by promises that are not fulfilled.
